tn.ref: In the second year of Jehoash son of Jehoahaz, king of Israel
tn.text: "When Jehoash son of Jehoahaz had been king of Israel for almost two years"

tn.ref: Amaziah son of Joash, king of Judah, began to reign
tn.text: "Amaziah son of Joash, became the king of Judah"

tn.ref: He was twenty-five years old when he began to reign
tn.text: five years old when he began to reign** - "He was 25 years old when he became king" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_numbers]])

tn.ref: he reigned twenty-nine years in Jerusalem
tn.text: nine years in Jerusalem** - "he was the king in Jerusalem for 29 years" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_numbers]])
(See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])

tn.ref: He did what was right in the eyes of Yahweh, yet not like David his father
tn.text: Here "the eyes of Yahweh" refers to his sight, and his sight refers to his judgment. AT: "Amaziah did many things that pleased Yahweh, but he did not do as many things that pleased Yahweh as King David had done" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: He did everything that Joash, his father, had done
tn.text: Joash obeyed Yahweh and did good things. This can be made explicit. AT: "He did the same good things that his father Joash had done" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
The story of Amaziah's rule as king of Judah continues.

tn.ref: But the high places were not taken away
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. The high places were used for pagan worship. This can be made explicit. AT: "But he did not remove the high places" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: sacrificed and burned incense at the high places
tn.text: The high places were used for pagan worship. This can be made explicit. AT: "sacrificed and burned incense to pagan gods at the high places"(See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
This is used to introduce a new event. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_newevent]])

tn.ref: as soon as his rule was well established
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "as soon as Amaziah securely established his royal rule and kingly authority" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
Amaziah probably ordered other people to kill the officials. AT: "he made his servants execute the officials" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
The narrator tells about what king Amaziah did after his father King Joash was murdered.

tn.ref: Yet he did not put the sons of the murderers to death
tn.text: King Amaziah did not order his servants to kill the children of the men who killed his father. AT: "But he did not tell his servants to execute those officials' children" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])

tn.ref: The fathers must not be put to death for their children, neither must the children be put to death for their parents
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "People must not kill the fathers for the sins of their children, and they must not kill the children for the sins of their parents" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: every person must be put to death for his own sin
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "every person must die for his own sin" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
Here "He" refers to his army. AT: "Amaziah's army killed" or "Amaziah's soldiers killed" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
"10,000 soldiers" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_numbers]])
This is the name of a place that is located south of the Dead Sea.

tn.ref: he also took Sela in war
tn.text: Here "He" refers to his army. AT: "King Amaziah's army captured the city of Sela" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
They renamed the city of Sela. The new name was Joktheel. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])

tn.ref: Then Amaziah sent messengers to Jehoash son of Jehoahaz son of Jehu king of Israel, saying, "Come, let us meet each other face to face in battle"
tn.text: Here "each other" also included their armies. AT: "Then Amaziah sent messengers to King Jehoash of Israel, saying, "Come here and let us and our armies fight each other in battle" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])

tn.ref: A thistle that was in Lebanon ... trampled down the thistle
tn.text: This is a word picture and a riddle. A cedar tree is great and a thistle is small and worthless. Jehoash compares himself to the cedar and Amaziah to the thistle and warns Amaziah not to attack. If you have a similar comparison in your own language, you can use it. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
"a bush with thorns"

tn.ref: saying, 'Give your daughter to my son for a wife,'
tn.text: This direct quotation can be stated as an indirect quotation. AT: "asking the cedar to give his daughter to the thistle's son for a wife" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_quotations]])
This is the warning part of Jehoash's message to Amaziah. "Amaziah, you have definitely defeated Edom"

tn.ref: your heart has lifted you up
tn.text: This is an idiom that refers to being proud. AT: "you are very proud of what you have done" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
"Be content with your victory"

tn.ref: for why should you cause yourself trouble and fall
tn.text: Jehoash uses this question to warn Amaziah not to attack him. AT: "for you should not cause trouble for yourself and suffer defeat" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
Here "listen" refers to obeying the warning. AT: "However, Amaziah would not obey Jehoash's warning" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: So Jehoash king of Israel attacked ... Amaziah king of Judah met each other
tn.text: The armies of these kings went to battle with them. AT: "So Jehoash and his army went to fight Amaziah and his army and they met each other" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
This is a town in Judah near the border of Israel. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
This can be stated in active form. AT: "Israel defeated Judah" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
"all the men in the army of Judah ran home"
This is what happened after the army of Israel defeated the army of Judah at Beth Shemesh.
Here "He" refers to Jehoash and his army. AT: "Jehoash and his army came ... Jehoash's soldiers took" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
There are the names of gates in the wall of Jerusalem. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
"about 180 meters" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_numbers]])
A cubit was about 46 centimeters. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_bdistance]])

tn.ref: with hostages also, and returned to Samaria
tn.text: This implies that Jehoash needed to take these hostages to prevent Amaziah from attacking again. This can be made explicit. AT: "and they also took to Samaria some prisoners to make sure that Amaziah would cause them no more trouble" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: are they not written in The Book of the Events of the Kings of Israel?
tn.text: This question is used to remind the reader that the acts of Jehoahaz are recorded in another book. See how this phrase is translated in [[:en:bible:notes:2ki:01:17|1:18]]. AT: "they are written in The Book of the Events of the Kings of Israel." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

tn.ref: Then Jehoash slept with his ancestors
tn.text: This is a polite way to say that he died. AT: "Then Jehoash died" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_euphemism]])
"became king after him"

tn.ref: are they not written in The Book of the Events of the Kings of Judah?
tn.text: This question is used to remind the reader that these things are recorded. See how this phrase is translated in [[:en:bible:notes:2ki:08:22|8:23]]. AT: "they are written in the book of the History of the Kings of Judah." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

tn.ref: They made a conspiracy against Amaziah in Jerusalem
tn.text: A conspiracy is a secret plan to do harm to someone or something. AT: "Some people in Jerusalem plotted against Amaziah"
This is a city in southwestern Judah. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])

tn.ref: but they sent men after him to Lachish
tn.text: The men who made the conspiracy sent other men to follow Amaziah to Lachish.
This is what happened after the death of King Amaziah.

tn.ref: They brought him back on horses
tn.text: "They brought Amaziah's body back on horses"

tn.ref: All the people of Judah took Azariah, who was sixteen years old, and made him king in place of his father Amaziah
tn.text: This is a generalization. Some people may not have wanted him to be king. AT: "The people of Judah took the 16 year-old Azariah and made him king after his father, Amaziah" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_hyperbole]])

tn.ref: It was Azariah who rebuilt Elath
tn.text: Azariah did not do this alone. AT: "It was Azariah who ordered Elath to be rebuilt" or "It was Azariah who supervised the rebuilding of Elath" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
This king is better known today by the name "Uzziah."
a city in Judah (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
"returned it to Judah"
This is a poetic way to say he died. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_euphemism]])
This describes what King Uzziah did after he became king.

tn.ref: In the fifteenth year of Amaziah
tn.text: "In year 15 of Amaziah" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_numbers]])
one years** - "41 years" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_numbers]])

tn.ref: evil in the sight of Yahweh
tn.text: Here "sight" is a metaphor for judging or considering. AT: "evil according to Yahweh" or "what Yahweh considered to be evil" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: He did not depart from any of the sins of Jeroboam
tn.text: To stop sinning is spoken of as leaving a path. This can be stated in positive form. AT: "He did not stop committing the same sins as Jeroboam" or "He continued to commit the same sins as Jeroboam" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

This means his army restored the land up to the border. AT: "His soldiers conquered again some of the territory that had previously belonged to Israel" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
This city was also called Hamath. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
"the Dead Sea" (UDB)
Suffering that was difficult is spoken of as if it had a bitter taste. AT: "it was very difficult" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: there was no rescuer for Israel
tn.text: "there was no one who could rescue Israel"
To completely destroy Israel is spoken of as if Yahweh wiped them away with a cloth. AT: "completely destroy" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
Here "the name of Israel" represents all of Israel and its inhabitants. AT: "the Israelite people" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
"on earth"

tn.ref: he saved them by the hand of Jeroboam son of Jehoash
tn.text: Here "hand" refers to power. Jeroboah defeated the enemies of Israel with the help of his army. AT: "he enabled King Jeroboam and his army to rescue them" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])

tn.ref: are they not written in The Book of the Events of the Kings of Israel?
tn.text: This question is used to remind the reader that the acts of Jehoahaz are recorded in another book. See how this phrase is translated in [[:en:bible:notes:2ki:01:17|1:18]]. AT: "they are written in The Book of the Events of the Kings of Israel." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

tn.ref: Jeroboam slept with his ancestors, with the kings of Israel
tn.text: This is a polite way to say that he died and was buried. AT: "Jeroboam died, and was buried where the other kings of Israel were buried" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_euphemism]])
